evidence.text: Person A: Pardon me for intruding. I met this casting director - unique and unusual physiognomies is his specialty - he told me you were holding auditions for this interesting-sounding play, he thought I might perhaps be a proper fit. I’m no actor, but I thought I’d come take a gander. From the tidbit I’ve just seen, I must say it looks like a very curious piece! But I see the role is filled, and quite ably. Cheers to all involved. Best of luck. Break a leg, as they say. I’ll come see it when it opens. Good day!
Person B: Wait, hold on.

Person B: Ah, the brilliant scribe!
Person A: And director.

Person A: Nonsense, you’re more than wanted! Though it’ll be nerve-wracking for us, the play is still nascent. Nothing set in stone.
Person A: Well, you’re - please - unless you’re busy.

Person A: One of my favorite books.
Person B: Strangely enough, I was inspired to read it by Guy. He has those piercing blue eyes, and I saw him, and thought “that reminds me...”
Person B: It could use some mild refinement, but we’ll get there.
Person B: Well, you’re not playing Master Harold after all.

Person A: Frankly, Guy, to keep you in the play. Look, this is hard for me but, you know I need Oswald to be Edward. And he refused unless there was a part for you, because he - loves you - and didn’t want it to be like he was...replacing you. And this is what we came up with. You should really be thanking Oswald.
Person A: This is my decision. I had to beg him to do it. Look, it’s not you, Guy, but, come on, the mask, the makeup, it’s a total bust, and Oswald...I mean...
Person A: You’re selling yourself short. You could play Hamlet.

Person B: You already know your lines.
Person B: You can. He can. You’ve seen it. We’ve all seen it. Oswald’s a natural. If it’s right, it’s right.

Person A: Guy, you’re a masterful actor. That’s what’s so tragic here, and I really don’t know what the ethical thing is.
Person B: The right thing is for you to take the role. And Guy, you still get to play Edward...transformed...and you don’t have to hide your face behind that idiotic thing, so you’ll get more recognition.
Person B: Same chap, new face.

Person A: I’m sorry, Guy. It doesn’t work. You said it yourself, how can he become you? You’re nothing alike. It’s not believable. And it’s not necessary. She loves him for who he is. It was contrived.
Person A: Look, I still want to be friends and I’ll keep you in for future projects. I’m sorry. Goodbye, Guy.

Person B: Well, I’m off. Anyone need anything?
Person A: I’ll walk you out.
Person B: Okay, we’ll get out of your hair. I’ll be back around eight.
Person A: We adopted Lucie, her daughter, who’s - it’s crazy to even say it - in grad school now.

Person B: Oh, come now. It was a very precocious “early work.” And it brought us together so it served a very noble purpose.
Person B: I was disappointed, I wanted to see that guy play me. Anyway, you’ll love the new show. I think it’s her finest work.
Person A: Going out on a high note.
Person B: Time will tell. You see, it’s brilliant that we ran into you, because we’re leaving next month after the play wraps.
Person B: As the Lord intended us to be.
Person A: Have you done LSD, Guy?

Person A: I’m not sure he could handle it.
Person A: Recently certified.
Person B: I’m sure Guy thinks it’s a cult as well. Right, Guy?
Person B: Totally bonkers.

Person A: Honestly, it’s, as far as I’m concerned, it’s paradise.
Person B: Paradise, it really is. Utopia, the closest thing.
Person B: Tell us everything.
